dorothy-wong.html.title: Dorothy WONG
dorothy-wong.html.description:
Born on: August 12, 1905 In: Walnut Grove, Sacramento, California, USA Died on: January 31, 1985 In: Los Angeles, California, USA Parents: WONG Ming Chong, JANG Hem Shee
Siblings: John Kuen Hue WONG, Jehim WONG, WONG Sam Tin, Lyda WONG, Abbie WONG
Married: C.C. CHEND
Children: Donaldson CHENG, Louis CHENG, Samuel CHENG, Robert CHENG, Annette CHENG, brother (still born, no name)
Tags: gen_b
On August 12, 1905. Dorothy Chuck Yee Wong was the second child born in the United States (Walnut Grove, CA) for her father WONG Ming Chong and mother JANG Hem. Her father had recently returned from China to bring JANG Hem, pregnant with Dorothy's elder sister Sam Foon WONG. Dorothy's father was a merchant with a partnership in the Chong Sing & Co at the time, located in Walnut Grove, a town on the Sacramento Delta.
The family moved to Watsonville, CA in 1909 so that Dorothy's father could take over the management of then-called Yee Lee Company, changing the name to the Wong Yee Kee Company. Dorothy's three younger brothers and two younger sisters were born.Revolutionary Sun Yat-sen is recalled to have visited Dorothy's home when she was at a young age. The family nickname for Sun Yat-sen was "Uncle Bean," which he earned from eating beans when staying at their place. They shared a hometown of Xiangshan, better known by its current name Zhongshan.
In 1921, at age 16, Dorothy embarked on the with her parents and siblings to return to , China. During this time, Dorothy had also acquired a Kodak Brownie, which she used to photograph her daily life. Dorothy attended the McTyeire School for Girls, a Christian school in Shanghai. Her parents stayed in Shanghai while she and her siblings eventually returning to the US, starting with Jehim.
She met Chee Chinn CHEND while __ and they married in on June 23, 1925, when Dorothy was 19 years old. They had four children, three sons and a daughter. By laws at the time, being a woman and having married a non-citizen meant that Dorthy lost her American citizenship. She encountered difficulty when petitioning for her re-naturalization, and had to present evidence that she had previously lived in the US because she did not possess a birth certificate. High school transcripts from Watsonville allowed her to become re-naturalized. She arrived to San Francisco with her oldest two sons Donaldson and Louis on January 24, 1949, and continued living in the Bay Area.
Meanwhile, C. C. and their younger two children remained in China. Dorothy wrote to her husband to urge him to come to the US soon with the impending control of the Chinese Communist Party over China. She vouched for his eligibility in a letter to the California __ [1].
Donaldson and Louis were attending university in 1949, supported by income from Dorothy's imports store, The Temple Bell. moving to LA, with brother Jehim's precedence LA Chinese Women's Club
Ran the Coral Sea Restaurant and the 5 Lanterns Restaurant LA Chinese Women's club recipe books introducing hot pot to american audience The restaurants were sold after the death of her husband C.C Chend. taught cooking interviewed for local news personal profile LA Times Obituary
?↩︎

Parents: WONG Ming Chong, JANG Hem Shee
Siblings: Dorothy WONG
Married: Edna Mae Fong On: Children:
Tags: gen_bJehim WONGBorn on: August 30, 1859 In: Zhongshan, Guangdong, China Died on: August 13, 1951 In: Shanghai, China Parents: Siblings:
Married: Yip Jang On: ? , Married: JANG Hem Shee On:
Children: With Yip Jang: four children. With JANG Hem Shee: WONG Young Ho, Sam Foon WONG,Dorothy WONG, John Kuen Hue WONG, Jehim WONG, Lyda WONG, Abbie WONG
Tags: gen_a first arrived in US 1881 (don’t know anything really from before) left at some point back to China came back to US in 1891, must have already had a partnership then but we haven’t found it 1893 Wing Sing Gue, not the main guy (Lee Dick is), Courtland CA 1899, not in wing sing gue anymore 1900, joins Chong Sing & Co in Walnut Grove CA 1902, becomes main guy of Chong Sing & Co, most others go back to China (including Lee Dick) sometime 1902-03, goes back to China 1903 came with wife Jang Hem/Jeung Hem (”start of our family history”) and older of their two daughters other had an eye infection, came later with her husband and eventual infant daughter immigration wouldn’t let Jang Hem off the boat at first, WMC wrote to W. A. Smith of Levis 1904 first daughter born in US is born (Sam Foon) 1905 second daughter born in US is born (Dorothy, Chuck Yee) 1906 earthquake, brought vegetables to the SF chinatown from walnut grove Sept 1906, first picture with hair grown out (anti-Qing) on partnership paper 1909 moved to watsonville, June 22, 1909 bought over dry goods store Wong Yee Kee Company (219 Main St. Watsonville, previously Yee Lee Company, a gambling den that got busted and got racist press coverage) c. 1916 photo in front of the store has the second daughter and family when they were visiting. Wanted to stay but were rejected (deemed “unfavorable” on immigration paper), stayed in Canada a while before going back to China May 1919 since then becomes officially sole owner (was really the sole owner except when he listed brother in law for when daughter was visiting) 1921 sold business and land (how did he own property?) and left for China with family (wife, 5 kids). Said he might come back in 5 years, but never did, spent rest of life in Shanghai. Filled out the 431 Form, stating they are leaving and intend on coming back WMC actually hired a lawyer Also part of the process was an interview where they got personal information that they would have to reproduce upon re-entry. Paperwork that exists: executive summary of interview, letter of approval (or disapproval), and transcribed interview Brought money back with him (bank statement) Approved June 16, left in July National ArchivesWONG Ming ChongBorn on: In: Died on: March 11, 1930 In: Shanghai, China Parents: Siblings:
Married: WONG Ming Chong
Children: Sam Foon WONG,Dorothy WONG, John Kuen Hue WONG, Jehim WONG, Lyda WONG, Abbie WONG
Tags: gen_aJANG Hem Shee

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
